Problem:
Consider a linear system governed by the equation \\( x'(t) = Lx(t) \\) where L is a linear operator on a function space, and the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) of \\( x(t) \\). Analyze how the system behaves under the Fourier transform and its inverse transform \\( \\mathcal{F}^{-1} \\).

If the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) is applied to the initial function \\( x_0 \\), and the resulting function is then evolved under \\( x'(t) = Lx(t) \\) without any intervention, will \\( \\mathcal{F}^{-1}x(t) \\) at t = T be the same as direct evolution of \\( x_0 \\) to t = T under \\( x'(t) = Lx(t) \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) and then evolving \\( x'(t) = Lx(t) \\) modifies how the system's state interacts with the operator L, especially since the spectral properties of L can differ in the transform space. The inverse Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}^{-1} \\) of the evolved state will generally not match the direct evolution of \\( x_0 \\) over time T.
